subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit 3.8.1: Maximum number of testXXX() methods
msgSnippet: PROBLEM SOLVED, but I still don t understand why. I was running the tests from ant using a  task. When I changed to using a  task, the errors go
messageBody:
PROBLEM SOLVED, but I still don't understand why.

I was running the tests from ant using a <java> task.
When I changed to using a <junit> task, the errors go
away.

--- Michael Silverstein <msilverstein@...>
wrote:
> Can you recreate it with a stripped down subclass of
> the generic test class?
> The JavaDoc for java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError says
> that it is thrown if
> the Java Virtual Machine or a classloader tries to
> load in the definition of
> a class (as part of a normal method call or as part
> of creating a new
> instance using the new expression) and no definition
> of the class could be
> found. The searched-for class definition existed
> when the currently
> executing class was compiled, but the definition can
> no longer be found.
>
> Anyway, I've never seen JUnit care about the number
> of tests, so I would
> guess it has something to do with your test itself
> or the classpath. Try
> putting a breakpoint in the exception to see how it
> got there. VA Java and
> Eclipse both enable you to do that. Not sure about
> the other IDEs.
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: eyl2k [mailto:eyl2k@...]
> > Sent: Friday, November 01, 2002 5:59 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit 3.8.1: Maximum number
> of testXXX() methods
> >
> >
> > I can't recreate it with a stripped down test. My
> test class extends a
> > generic test class that our project group uses.
> The generic test class
> > imports many packages, etc.
> >
> > I'll just have to live with it for now until I get
> more time to pursue
> > this issue.
> >
> > Thanks.
> >
> > --- In junit@y..., "Michael Silverstein"
> <msilverstein@s...> wrote:
> > > This is very odd. Could you post the test -
> especially if you can
> > recreate
> > > the problem with the insides of the test methods
> stripped out for
> > brevity.
> > >
> > > ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> > > Mike Silverstein
> > > SilverMark, Inc.
> > > The object testing company
> > > http://www.javatesting.com
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: eyl2k [mailto:eyl2k@y...]
> > > > Sent: Friday, November 01, 2002 5:18 PM
> > > > To: junit@y...
> > > > Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit 3.8.1: Maximum
> number of testXXX() methods
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > My interim workaround is to change all the
> names of the testXXX()
> > > > methods to xtestXXX() and then call each one
> manually from testAll().
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > --- In junit@y..., "eyl2k" <eyl2k@y...> wrote:
> > > > > MyTestCase with 5 testXXX() methods runs as
> expected. When I added a
> > > > > sixth testXXX() method, I get the following
> error message:
> > > > > [java] java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:
> > > > > sun/reflect/ConstructorAccessorImpl
> > > > >
> > > > > When I comment out one of the original
> testXXX() methods, everything
> > > > > runs as expected, so the 6th testXXX()
> method I added is fine.
> > > > >
> > > > > I checked the FAQ but couldn't find this
> issue discussed.
> > > > >
> > > > > Thanks for any information.
> > > >
> > > >
